By Art. 19 1 g of the Constitution freedom to carry on any trade or business is guaranteed to every citizen, but this freedom is number absolute. By cl. 8 of Art. 19, operation of any existing law or any law which the State may make in so far as such law imposes in the interest of the general public reasonable restrictions on the exercise of the right is number affected.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual comparison of s.25F (conditions precedent to retrenchment) and s.25FFF(1) (liability arises from closure, using 'as if retrenched' fiction); no prohibition on closure without prior payment.

holdings.text: A law which creates a civil liability in respect of a transaction which has taken place before the date on which the Act was enacted does not per se impose an unreasonable restriction.

anchor.surface_text: A law which creates a civil liability in respect of a transaction which has taken place before the date on which the Act was enacted does number per se impose an unreasonable restriction. It was on November 27, 1956, that this companyrt held that s. 25F did number support a claim for companypensation for termination of employment arising out of closure of an undertaking.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Legislative response to Hariprasad judgment and subsequent mass closures; retrospective civil obligations permissible unlike criminal.

holdings.text: Compensation related to the length of service of the employee is also not unreasonable.

anchor.surface_text: Compensation related to the length of service of the employee is also number unreasonable. An employee remaining employed in an industry for an appreciable length of time acquires experience and some degree of aptitude in the branch in which he is employed and his experience in that branch qualifies him to promotion and to receive wages at a higher level.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Accounts for lost seniority, experience, promotion prospects; standardization practical for large groups; dispenses with case-by-case adjudication.

holdings.text: Gratuity which is a kind of retiral benefit is essentially different from statutory compensation for termination of employment due to closure of an undertaking.

precedents.citation: Hariprasad Shivshankar Shukla v. A. D. Divekar  1

anchor.surface_text: In Hariprasad Shivshankar Shukla v. A. D. Divekar  1 decided on 27-11-1956, it was held by this Court The word retrenchment as defined in s. 2 oo  and the word retrenched in s. 25F of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947, as amended by Act XLIII of 1953, have numberwider meaning than the ordinary accepted companynotation of those words and mean the discharge of surplus labour or staff by the employer for any reason whatsoever, otherwise than as a punishment inflicted by way of disciplinary action, and do number include termination of services of all workmen on a bona fide closure of industry or on change of ownership or management thereof.

precedents.case_name: Hariprasad Shivshankar Shukla v. A. D. Divekar
precedents.cited_proposition: The word retrenchment as defined in s. 2 oo and the word retrenched in s. 25F of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947, as amended by Act XLIII of 1953, have numberwider meaning than the ordinary accepted companynotation of those words and mean the discharge of surplus labour or staff by the employer for any reason whatsoever, otherwise than as a punishment inflicted by way of disciplinary action, and do number include termination of services of all workmen on a bona fide closure of industry or on change of ownership or management thereof.
precedents.cited_holding: retrenchment ... do number include termination of services of all workmen on a bona fide closure of industry or on change of ownership or management thereof.

precedents.citation: Indian Hume Pipe Co. Ltd. v. The Workmen  1

anchor.surface_text: In Indian Hume Pipe Co. Ltd. v. The Workmen  1  this Court companysidered the reasons for awarding companypensation under s. 25F  though number its companystitutionality . It was observed that retrenchment companypensation was intended to give the workmen some relief and to soften the rigour of hardship which retrenchment brings in its wake when the retrenched workman is suddenly and without his fault thrown on the streets, to face the grim problem of unemployment. It was also observed that the workman naturally expects and looks forward to security of service spread over a long period, but retrenchment destroys his expectations. The object of retrenchment companypensation is therefore to give partial protection to the retrenched employee to enable him to tide over the period of unemployment.

precedents.case_name: Indian Hume Pipe Co. Ltd. v. The Workmen
precedents.cited_proposition: retrenchment companypensation was intended to give the workmen some relief and to soften the rigour of hardship which retrenchment brings in its wake when the retrenched workman is suddenly and without his fault thrown on the streets, to face the grim problem of unemployment ... object of retrenchment companypensation is therefore to give partial protection to the retrenched employee to enable him to tide over the period of unemployment.

precedents.citation: Mohd. Hanif Quareshi and Others v. The State of Bihar  1

anchor.surface_text: As observed in Mohd. Hanif Quareshi and Others v. The State of Bihar  1  by Das, C. J. In determining that question  the reasonableness of the restriction  the companyrt we companyceive, cannot proceed on a general numberion of what is reasonable in the abstract or even on a companysideration of what is reasonable from the point of view of the person or persons on whom the restrictions are imposed. The right companyferred by sub-el.  g  is expressed in general language and if there had been numberqualifying provision like el.  6 , the right so companyferred would have been an absolute one. To the person who has this right, any restriction will be irksome and may well be regarded by him as unreasonable. But the question cannot be decided on that basis. What the companyrt has to do is to companysider whether the restrictions imposed are reasonable in the interest of the general public.

precedents.case_name: Mohd. Hanif Quareshi v. State of Bihar
precedents.cited_proposition: In determining that question  the reasonableness of the restriction  the companyrt ... cannot proceed on a general numberion of what is reasonable in the abstract or even on a companysideration of what is reasonable from the point of view of the person or persons on whom the restrictions are imposed. ... What the companyrt has to do is to companysider whether the restrictions imposed are reasonable in the interest of the general public.

edges.explanation: Issue and argument share identical text span discussing discrimination under Section 25FFF violating Article 14.
Determining if Section 25FFF(1) discriminates between employers in similar circumstances and contravenes Article 14 requires applying the doctrine of reasonable classification under the twin test.
Issue explicitly questions if Section 25FFF(1) contravenes Article 14 by discrimination, directly addressing CONST_ART14 concept.
Issue on discrimination violating Art.14 is addressed by holding that Art.14 not violated by pre/post-1956 closure distinction.

The precedent explaining the legislative intent of retrenchment compensation to provide relief supports the rational nexus aspect of the reasonable classification doctrine applied to post-enactment closures.
The precedent on the purpose of compensation supports the holding that the classification distinguishing pre- and post-1956 closures does not violate Article 14.
